posts.title: Exclusive Starbucks mug at Universal Orlando Resort featuring theme park icons
posts.text:
I’m pretty sure that in America, coffee is king. And if that is the case, Starbucks pretty much holds court everywhere, including theme parks. Well, Universal Orlando Resort just received a new scepter in the form of an exclusive Starbucks mug that features the parks famous icons. 
The three Starbucks on Universal property will carry this sure-to-be-in-demand beauty, so you should be able to find it in Universal CityWalk, Universal Studios Florida, and Universal’s Islands of Adventure. The mug depicts popular park icons like the classic arches, the towering lighthouse, and the rotating globe which has stood as the brand’s “mascot” since before the parks were even created. 
Made of a thick ceramic, the mug holds a full 14 ounces of life-giving caffeinated bliss. And the piece is microwave and dishwasher safe to boot. How that for putting a little frappe in your cappuccino?

thread.title: Starbucks (SBUX) Has Ambitious Plans to Increase Same-Store Sales
thread.title_full: Starbucks (SBUX) Has Ambitious Plans to Increase Same-Store Sales - TheStreet

posts.author: Natalie Walters
posts.title: Starbucks (SBUX) Has Ambitious Plans to Increase Same-Store Sales
posts.text:
Starbucks ( SBUX ) has a number of future plans in place to continue to grow the business and increase same-store sales, even as current CEO Howard Schultz is preparing to hand the reins of the coffee company over to current COO Kevin Johnson.
"I can't try to be Howard. I'm not Howard," Johnson said in an in-depth interview with Schultz on CNBC's "Squawk Box" earlier on Friday.
Johnson intends to lead the company on its "most ambitious strategic plan in the history of the company," he said. That plan includes "elevating the brand," "elevating the customer experience" and "amplifying Starbucks as a destination."
Specifically, Starbucks will be working to extend mobile pay to its license partners and other geographies, Johnson said. "That's a big unlock," he said.
Second, Starbucks is going to expand its food options, Johnson claimed. Its breakfast sandwiches have been a success, but the next frontier will be whether it can "crack the code" on lunch options.
Third, the company is working on building its upscale Starbucks Reserve brand by opening up 20 to 30 roasteries, as well as 1,000-plus stores in the same "theme" as the roasteries, Schultz commented. The stores will be about 4,000 square feet, which is twice the size of existing Starbucks stores, and will offer coffee that runs up to $12 per cup. In addition, existing stores will get Reserve bars added to them.
So far, the 15,000 square-foot Seattle roastery that opened about two years ago has "far exceeded our expectations," Schultz claimed. "It has four times the average ticket of a typical Starbucks store and has become a primary destination for every tourist in Seattle."

thread.title: Starbucks (SBUX) CEO Schultz on Stepping Down: 'I'm at Peace With It'
thread.title_full: Starbucks (SBUX) CEO Schultz on Stepping Down: 'I'm at Peace With It' - TheStreet

posts.author: Natalie Walters
posts.title: Starbucks (SBUX) CEO Schultz on Stepping Down: 'I'm at Peace With It'
posts.text:
Starbucks ( SBUX ) CEO Howard Schultz announced on Thursday that he would step down from his position in early April, but this isn't the first time he's attempted the transition.
Schultz first planned to leave the company back in 2000 when he became chairman, but he returned in 2008 to help fix falling sales. Looking back, there were two main issues that made that first transition unsuccessful, Schultz said in an in-depth interview along with his successor and current Starbucks COO Kevin Johnson on CNBC's "Squawk Box" on Friday.
First, he left at the start of the "cataclysmic" financial crisis and his company had "a very difficult time navigating through that," Schultz said. "We did not have the quality of the team. We didn't have the resources and the capabilities that we have now. We didn't have the leader."
Second, Schultz wasn't "emotionally prepared to leave the company and not meddle" back then, he said. This time around, Schultz has a full-time project ahead of him, with expanding the new upscale Starbucks Reserve Brand, which is expected to have as many as 1,000 locations.
While Schultz says he is in a "good position personally" this time around, the reality of the change didn't hit him until he actually said the words on Thursday. "When you're in front of everybody and you make the announcement and it's real, you realize you've crossed over the Rubicon."
Schultz is "at peace with it," he added. Starbucks is healthy, and Johnson is a trustworthy partner, he said.

thread.title: Incoming Starbucks CEO Kevin Johnson Is 'Impressive' -- Analyst
thread.title_full: Incoming Starbucks CEO Kevin Johnson Is 'Impressive' -- Analyst - TheStreet

posts.author: Giovanni Bruno
posts.title: Incoming Starbucks CEO Kevin Johnson Is 'Impressive' -- Analyst
posts.text:
Effective April 3, 2017, Starbucks ( SBUX ) CEO Howard Schultz will hand the reins of CEO over to current Chief Operating Officer Kevin Johnson, the company announced Thursday. Schultz will assume the role of Executive Chairman and spearhead innovation focused on the development of high-end roastery locations.
"I was a little bit surprised by the timing," Morningstar's R.J. Hottovy told CNBC Friday morning. "I think the company set this transition in motion this summer when they reorganized the executive positions."
 Starbucks is a holding in Jim Cramer's Action Alerts PLUS Charitable Trust Portfolio . Want to be alerted before Cramer buys or sells SBUX ? Learn more now .
Starbucks announced a reorganization this summer, giving Schultz oversight of day-to-day operations.
"I thought this might have been something we see a year or two down the road," Hottovy said.
Yet Hottovy came away "impressed" by Johnson from the CNBC interview that included both Schultz and the incoming CEO on Friday morning.
He said that while it is impossible to replace someone with the business acumen of Schultz, Johnson confidently answered crucial questions about the retail side of the company.
"I think that he accurately answered that you really can't [discuss] customer experience in the stores without the digital flywheel. I think the company is well ahead of the curve on that end," Hottovy noted.
Furthermore, Schultz emphasized Starbucks' bench, which he has called the strongest in Starbucks' history.
"I think Howard's point about a deeper bench is absolutely true," Hottovy said. "Every one of the positions they have, all these guys are at the top of their field."

thread.title_full: You're Going to Regret Selling Starbucks: More Squawk From Jim Cramer - TheStreet

posts.author: Natalie Walters
posts.title: You're Going to Regret Selling Starbucks: More Squawk From Jim Cramer - TheStreet
posts.text:
Shares of Starbucks ( SBUX ) were down 2.8% Friday, the day after Howard Schultz, the CEO and face of the company, announced that he would be stepping down from his position effective on April 3 and would be replaced by COO Kevin Johnson. Schultz will remain executive chairman of the coffee company. The stock dropped as much as 10% when Schultz first made the announcement.
"When we got the news, I was immediately very disappointed because I love what Howard has done. He is iconic," TheStreet's Jim Cramer said on CNBC's "Squawk on the Street" Friday. "The natural reaction is to say, 'Wait a minute, he is Steve Jobs and you can't do Starbucks without Howard," he added.
However, Cramer said he feels better now after interviewing Schultz and Johnson on CNBC's "Squawk Box" this morning because he realized Schultz "really isn't going anywhere." Said Cramer, in the interview, Schultz effectively said, "I'm still very much involved, but we do have technology problems. And Kevin is better at that."
The tech problem at Starbucks is currently its "biggest problem," Cramer claimed. It hasn't fully worked out the mobile order because the lines are too long and the throughputs aren't good. Johnson may be better at fixing that issue because of his past experience as an executive at Microsoft ( MSFT ) and Juniper Networks ( JNPR ) . "If you're going to figure out throughput, you're not going to be a coffee man...that's not a slight to Howard. That's a tech job," he explained.
